column1: Saint-Germain-en-Laye (French: [sɛ̃.ʒɛʁmɛ̃.ɑ̃.lɛ] (listen)) is a commune in the Yvelines department in the Île-de-France in north-central France. It is located in the western suburbs of Paris
column2: 19.1 km (11.9 mi) from the centre of Paris.

column1: Inhabitants are called Saint-Germanois or Saint-Germinois. With its elegant tree-lined streets it is one of the more affluent suburbs of Paris
column2: combining both high-end leisure spots and exclusive residential neighborhoods (see the Golden Triangle of the Yvelines).

column1: Saint-Germain-en-Laye is a sub-prefecture of the department. Because it includes the National Forest of Saint-Germain-en-Laye
column2: it covers approximately 48 km2 (19 sq mi)
column3: making it the largest commune in the Yvelines. It occupies a large loop of the Seine. Saint-Germain-en-Laye lies at one of the western termini of Line A of the RER.

column1: Saint-Germain-en-Laye was founded in 1020 when King Robert the Pious (ruled 996–1031) founded a convent on the site of the present Church of Saint-Germain.

column3: King of England and VII of Scotland
column4: exiled himself to the city after being deposed from the throne in what has become known as the Glorious Revolution. He spent the remainder of his days there

column1: Prior to the French Revolution in 1789
column2: it had been a royal town and the Château de Saint-Germain the residence of numerous French monarchs. The old château was constructed in 1348 by King Charles V on the foundations of an old castle (château-fort) dating from 1238 in the time of Saint Louis.  Francis I was responsible for its subsequent restoration.  In 1862
column3: Napoleon III set up the Musée des Antiquités Nationales in the erstwhile royal château. This museum has exhibits ranging from Paleolithic to Celtic times.  The "Dame de Brassempouy" sculpted on a mammoth's ivory tusk around 23
column4: 000 years ago is the most famous exhibit in the museum.

column1: Kings Henry IV and Louis XIII left their mark on the town. Louis XIV was born in the château (the city's coat of arms consequently shows a cradle and the date of his birth)
column2: and established Saint-Germain-en-Laye as his principal residence from 1661 to 1681. Louis XIV turned over the château to James VII & II of Scotland and England after his exile from Britain after the Glorious Revolution in 1688. James lived in the Château for 13 years
column3: and his daughter Louisa Maria Stuart was born in exile here in 1692. James II is buried in the Church of Saint-Germain.

column1: Saint-Germain-en-Laye is famous for its 2.4-kilometre (1.5 mi) long stone terrace built by André Le Nôtre from 1669 to 1673.  The terrace provides a view over the valley of the Seine and
column4: the name was changed along with many other places whose names held connotations of religion or royalty. Temporarily
column5: Saint-Germain-en-Laye became Montagne-du-Bon-Air. During his reign
column6: Napoleon I established his cavalry officers training school in the Château-Vieux.

column1: The Treaty of Saint-Germain was signed in 1919 and was applied on 16 July 1920. The treaty officially registered the breakup of the Habsburg empire
column2: which recognized the independence of Czechoslovakia
column5: and the Kingdom of the Serbs
column7: and Slovenes (Yugoslavia).During the occupation from 1940 to 1944
column8: the town was the headquarters of the German Army.

column2: the former commune Fourqueux was merged into Saint-Germain-en-Laye.

column1: Saint Germain en Laye is connected to other communes by the Résalys bus network operated by Transdev Montesson-les-Rabeaux. Saint-Germain-en-Laye is served by Saint-Germain-en-Laye station on Paris RER line A.

It is also served by two stations on the Transilien Paris – Saint-Lazare suburban rail line: [[Saint-Germain – Bel-Air – Fourqueux (SNCF)|Saint-Germain – Bel-Air – Fourqueux] ] and Saint-Germain – Grande Ceinture.

Saint-Germain-en-Laye is also served by Achères – Grand Cormier station on Paris RER line A and on the Transilien Paris – Saint-Lazare suburban rail line. This station is located in the middle of the Forest of Saint-Germain-en-Laye
column2: far away from the urbanized part of the commune.

column1: Saint-Germain-en-Laye has a proud footballing history. From 1904 to 1970 it was represented by Stade Saint-Germain which
column2: following a 1970 merger with Paris FC
column3: became Paris Saint-Germain (PSG). They are a top-flight football team who have won several French football cups and one C2 cup. PSG are the highest ranking team in France.
